metadata.h1: Unlock IoT Data You Already Have
metadata.description: Machine learning greatly benefit from the Internet of Things. But the IoT sensors are difficult to scale. Here are 5 existing systems you should tap into.

all_paragraphs: Machine learning models greatly benefit from IoT sensor data. AI and IoT have long been two peas in a pod, just ask Wired.

The Internet of Things (IoT) is all fun and games until it is time to buy sensors. IoT is notoriously difficult to scale and manage — 30% of IoT projects never make it past the proof-of-concept stage.

But what if I told you that you already have untapped IoT sensor data in your buildings? Every modern commercial building is packed full of sensors. They are already installed and managed at scale. The problem is they are closed systems for single-purpose applications.
But if you can unlock the sensor data, they can power many data science projects without requiring new hardware.
Here are 5 enterprise systems you should explore tapping into:
BMS includes a handful of technologies that regulate the building environment. Most commonly, they include lighting control systems and HVAC (air condition) systems.

The most basic lighting control systems include motion sensors in rooms and walkways — you’ve probably had to wave your arms around in a room before when the lights cut off. More advanced lighting control systems include lumen sensors near windows that dim the lights to save power in areas where there is more natural light.
The HVAC system includes temperature sensors throughout the building to regulate cooling and heating based on where it is needed.

Both these systems have environmental sensors all over the building — it just takes some creative integration to make those sensor feed available to IoT applications. In fact, this transition is already happening because BMS applications benefit from IoT integration.

As the grandfather of the Internet of Things, RTLS has proven how IoT can deliver value for over a decade. In fact, the RTLS market is expected to grow to nearly $12B by 2024.

RTLS includes tags that are placed on assets or people that a business wants to track location. Those tags communicate with a dedicated infrastructure of sensors and gateways. Based on those communications, an algorithm calculated the tag’s estimated location on an indoor floor plan.
RTLS is used to reduce time spend looking for things and automate workflows that have location-driven events. An RTLS is a goldmine of contextual data for IoT applications.
Here’s a pseudo dataset of what you might get from an RTLS:
Just about every commercial building has security cameras for basic surveillance. At a minimum, they are used to record activity in case evidence is needed for a crime committed on-premises.

For a while now, these security surveillance systems have been transitioning from old school COAX connections to IP-based connections that are accessible on your internal network. The growth of cellular video camera connections is expected to grow from 3.7M in 2019 to over 20M by 2024.

Computer Vision (CV) can be used on these existing video streams to collect contextual data and generate alerts. CV is powered by machine learning (ML) models that are trained to recognize objects, people, and events in a series of images.
Here’s a pseudo dataset of what you might get from a CV algorithm:
Most offices don’t just let anyone waltz in — you need to prove that you’re allowed to be there. Access control systems power those badge readers you tap to unlock doors.
Typically these badge readers use passive RFID technology. That means that the reader does all the work so the badge doesn’t need a battery.
An employee badge is effectively an IoT device. It is a small, physical representation of an employee’s identity and credentials.

Some IoT applications require identifying people to power personalized experiences. But no one wants to carry around yet another “thing” just to actuate an IoT solution. Not everyone wants their phone to be tracked either — last year major news outlets urged consumers to disable location tracking.
The employee badge and your access control system are a repeatable model for inputting human identity into an IoT application.
Here’s a pseudo dataset of what you might get from an access control system:
People need to connect to the Internet. Ethernet just doesn’t cut it anymore — Wireless Internet connectivity is a given in almost all commercial environments.
Each of those Wi-Fi access points in the ceiling acts as a gateway for network connectivity. But did you consider they can also be an IoT gateway?
Some sensor endpoints can backhaul over Wi-Fi so you don’t have to buy standalone IoT gateways. The tradeoff is that Wi-Fi connectivity increases the power consumption of small IoT devices.
To help fix that, many Wi-Fi vendors are adding other wireless communication radios to their access points, such as:
These radios are more power-friendly for IoT devices, which means they can last longer on a battery without sacrificing performance.
Check your Wi-Fi access points to see what wireless radios they have that can be used for IoT backhaul.

Lastly, enterprise Wi-Fi vendors often provide analytics tools, such as Cisco’s DNA platform or Aruba’s Operational Intelligence platform, to their customer’s IT network support teams. While they focus on performance metrics for issue resolution, these systems also often capture client data that can be used to understand who’s devices are connected where.
Based on the pseudo datasets above, these systems have data to tell a compelling story if they aren’t locked up in isolation.
